posts.cooked: Hi everyone, I’m currently doing some research on acquiring a 3D printer for my team. Thus, I’d like to know what filaments are actually being used for FRC , and if things like nylon, ABS/ASA, and polycarbonate filaments are actually worth the price. Or are PLA filaments just fine for competition robots? Basically asking this so that I can decide whether to focus on enclosed, or unenclosed printer options.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: We use PETG and carbon PETG for basically everything. Extremely easy to print and significantly more durable than PLA.

posts.name: Brett
posts.cooked: We use a prusament pc-cf and sirayatech cf-pet for gears and pulleys. They both have really good strength and impact resistance. We generally use more of the cf-pet because it’s relatively cheap and for most small parts you don’t need to have an enclosure.
How often do you deal with failed prints? In my experience PETG takes a lot of care for keeping it dry and avoiding parts with overhangs.
So you’re printing Polycarbonate CF without an enclosure?
PLA-CF and PETG-CF. FLASHFORGE brand printed on a Bambu Labs X1C.

posts.name: Chris Cross
posts.cooked: We have a Bambu X1C.  Very few failed prints. We will typically do test prints in PLA. Most printed parts that make it onto the robot are either PETG or PETG-CF.  We have used PA-CF but don’t really see a performance difference to justify the extra cost in most cases.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: We almost never have failed prints. It’s always a good idea to store filament in a dry box, but if you do a lot of printing and stick to one color you’re likely to go through a spool before you have moisture issues.

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked: Prusament PCCF is designed to and prints great without an enclosure. It is abrasive so you want it to have a hardened steel filament path, but I’ve printed it for years on my Mk3 and then Bambu Lab machines without issue. It is probably my favorite performance filament for the combination of ease of use and strength. It’s not quite as good as a PACF filament like Onyx, but it is a lot less annoying to deal with, as it typically has little to no issues with water absorption.

posts.name: Brett
posts.cooked: No, polycarbotnate is too finicky, but the cf-pet you can. We have done it before but it warps a lot and is far less dimensionally accurate

posts.name: Nick Aarestad
posts.cooked: I’m surprised you’ve had issues with PCCF without an enclosure. What machines are you running it on?

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked: I have used multiple types of filaments…I am about to try Fiberon PA6-GF25.  So…I am about to find out is going to work for us.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.name: CEF
posts.cooked: Have you found that the added carbon fiber actually does anything?  My impression is that it really doesn’t – it just makes the print a bit fuzzier.

posts.name: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons
posts.cooked:
I used CF last season…no real strength…that I could see.

And you are right…fuzzy without the fuzzy setting.
posts.display_username: Ric Ferrell Mentor for 5503 Tiger Trons

posts.cooked: Seeing a lot of people using Carbon Fiber infused filaments, not trying to create any sort of scare here, but have you looked into the fact that most CF filaments will shed carbon fibers from the outer walls of printed parts and then those fibers can become embedded it your hands? Are you doing anything about that such as using a  clear coat on CF infused parts?

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked: CF fill generally results in an overall reduction of material strength relative to the raw polymer.  The advantages that CF fill offers are two things. #1 is increasing stiffness significantly. #2 , and most important in my opinion, is stabilizing high warpage materials like nylon and polycarbonate to allow hobby class machines to print large parts with accuracy and no cracking.

posts.name: ehochstein
posts.cooked:
461 has recently utilized parts made in PLA, PETG, ASA, Nylon 12 and Polypropylene.

I made a post awhile back on the printers that we were using: 461 WBI | Additive Manufacturing Lab

Since that point in time we have restructured the lab a bit to include: 1 - Bambu Lab X1C for printing advanced materials (Filled Nylon, TPUs, etc.), these are production parts for FTC and FRC . We have a material dryer from Polymaker that ensures the material we are printing with is dry. We’ll probably upgrade this to the BambuLab drier in the future. 3 - Bambu Lab P1S for printing in PLA and PETG with an AMS. Prototyping for FRC and production parts for our FTC teams. Our FLL teams often ask to use these printers for their projects as well. 1 - Fortus 380MC for printing parts in ASA. We use these parts for production for both our FRC and FTC robots.

For the upcoming year we’re planning on adding a H1D or two and maybe a larger fleet of A1 or P1 systems. We’re waiting on approval for a grant before we make the purchase.

If you’re just starting out, I would suggest looking at the enclosed line of Bambu Lab printers and start with PLA/PETG. Once you build some skills in the process, expand to more advanced filaments (TPUs, Nylons) and filled (carbon, glass) filaments.

826leoguy:

Seeing a lot of people using Carbon Fiber infused filaments, not trying to create any sort of scare here, but have you looked into the fact that most CF filaments will shed carbon fibers from the outer walls of printed parts and then those fibers can become embedded it your hands?

I have not experienced or seen this issue.

posts.name: Kyle Swaidner
posts.cooked:
I try to point out every time I see a similar statement that modern “tough” or “impact resistant” PLA varieties are actually more durable than PETG.  This is particularly true under high strain rate impacts where PETG tends to experience a sort of brittle failure mode.

PETG does have the major advantage of a significantly improved heat deflection temperature such that your parts won’t deform badly in a car or trailer on a sunny day.

We primarily use PLA filament for most of our prints, while PETG is occasionally utilized depending on the application. Additionally, naturel PLA and PETG might be particularly useful in electronics projects, especially for monitoring status lights or for visual inspection purposes.
